intro: Heterocarpus oligotrichus, commonly known as the mangrove apple, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of Southeast Asia. It is a member of the Rhizophoraceae family and is characterized by its ability to thrive in saline and brackish water environments. The plant has distinctive prop roots that help stabilize it in soft, waterlogged soils. Its flowers are small and clustered, and it produces fleshy, red berries that are an important food source for various wildlife. The species plays a vital role in coastal ecosystems by preventing erosion and providing habitat for marine and terrestrial organisms.
